A Legacy Rebuilt: Empowering Dreams Through Education  

I‚Äôm deeply moved to share a personal milestone that intertwines my family‚Äôs history with the future of 2,000 children. As a Board Director of The Agrawal Foundation, I‚Äôve had the privilege of contributing to the vision that revitalized Shri 3 Chandra Secondary School in Kalaiya, Nepal‚Äîa place that once opened doors for my mother and her brothers, shaping the trajectory of our family‚Äôs story.

Growing up, I listened to stories of how this humble school gave them the courage to dream beyond their circumstances.

Two years ago, the foundation led by Dr. Bajrang Agrawal and Pawan Agrawal, embarked on a mission to honor that legacy. By championing the school‚Äôs complete renovation, the foundation and it‚Äôs partners has transformed it into a vibrant space where today‚Äôs students can learn, imagine, and aspire without limits.

 A Circle of Gratitude
This journey came full circle when the leaders of the city and the school came together and honored our foundation with a Certificate of Appreciation, recognizing our collective impact on education and community. It‚Äôs a testament to what happens when vision meets collaboration.

To the children of Nepal: May this school be your launchpad. To my peers and partners: Thank you for turning a personal legacy into a shared mission. And to every child who walks these halls‚Äîdream boldly. The world is waiting for you.

Costas K. G.
Costas K. G.
postsData.content:
Leadership is a deal.

A real leader doesn‚Äôt just give orders.

A real leader makes a deal.
With their team.
With their vision.
With themselves.

This deal is simple:
I will show up.
I will lift others.
I will build something bigger than myself.

The key for this is learning.

The more you learn
The more you begin to see learning as a form of leadership.

And not just that, learning is leadership at scale.

You will realize that if you really want to make an impact...
Learning will shape your leadership more than just about anything else.

Because:
You can‚Äôt lead others if you stop growing yourself.
A leader who learns stays open, adapts, and improves.
A leader who stops learning falls behind.

That‚Äôs the real deal of leadership.
And it changes everything.

4 Deals you need to make as a Leader:

1. Deal with your Team
- Listen more than you talk.
- Give credit, take the blame.
- Lift people up, don‚Äôt push them down.

2. Deal with your Vision
- Stand for something, not just anything.
- Make hard choices, not easy excuses.
- Stay focused when things get messy.

3. Deal with Yourself
- Do the work before asking others to.
- Keep your word, even when no one is watching.
- Stay humble. No one follows a leader who only serves themselves.

4. Deal with the Future
- Think beyond today, build something that lasts.
- Invest in people, not just results.
- Lead in a way that inspires others to lead too.

People don‚Äôt rise to the standard you demand.
They rise to the standard you set.

Learn to share.
Share to lead by example.
Lead by example to multiply impact.

That's the deal.
If you break the deal, people stop following.
If you honor it, they‚Äôll go all in with you.

---

For most of my life, I measured success by how much money I made. On my 30th birthday, I cried for days because I didn‚Äôt have my private jet. I made a promise to myself: By 40, I will have it.

Well‚Ä¶ my birthday is next week, and I still don‚Äôt have a private jet. In fact, every dollar I make, I reinvest into.

So I had to ask myself‚Äîis money really the right metric for success?

Or should we measure success by:

How many lives we‚Äôve changed?

How much joy we bring to people?

How many trees did we save on this planet?

I decided to look back on the last 10 years. If I measure by money alone, I might feel like I‚Äôve failed. But if I measure by impact, here‚Äôs what I see:

 I‚Äôve built six companies‚Äîtwo of them are growing fast.

 I‚Äôve helped over 100 businesses worldwide, saving several from bankruptcy and preventing thousands of layoffs.

 I‚Äôve changed the lives of at least 1,000 people, bringing joy, inspiration, and opportunity.

 I created SWAY, an alternative to traditional management that has already impacted 34 industries.

 I‚Äôve trained and empowered over 100 business coaches, helping them find success and support businesses.

 I learned English from scratch, became a speaker in 21 countries, and moved to the USA with my son.

 I‚Äôve cleaned plastic from rivers, delivered fresh food to those in need, and contributed to making the world a better place.

What if success isn‚Äôt about money‚Äîbut about kindness, joy, and the energy we share with people, animals, and nature?

What if we measured success not by the dollars in our bank accounts but by the positive impact we create‚Äîdaily, weekly, or yearly?

On my 30th birthday, I cried because I didn‚Äôt have a private jet.
On my 40th, I will celebrate the impact I‚Äôve made on this planet.

And I promise‚Äîto give even more in the next 10 years.

 How do you measure success?

postsData.content:
Great leaders adapt to change. Poor leaders resist change.


Because leadership isn‚Äôt about fitting a mold. It‚Äôs evolving to meet the moment.

According to Harvard Business Review, 70% of leadership development comes from on-the-job experiences.

Which means the best leaders aren‚Äôt just born‚Äîthey‚Äôre built.

Understanding leadership theories helps you refine your approach and lead with impact.

Study my 9 essential leadership theories every leader must know:

1. Great Man Theory
‚Ü≥ Leaders are born, not made. This outdated idea sparked leadership studies but ignores the power of growth and learning.

2. Trait Theory
‚Ü≥ Leadership is about personality traits‚Äîlike confidence, intelligence, and decisiveness. While useful for self-assessment, traits alone don‚Äôt make a great leader.

3. Behavioral Theory
‚Ü≥ Leaders are made, not born. This theory focuses on actions over traits, proving that leadership skills can be learned and developed.

4. Transformational Leadership
‚Ü≥ Inspires, mentors, and empowers. Transformational leaders create high-performing teams, but this style requires strong vision and adaptability.

5. Transactional Leadership
‚Ü≥ A system of rewards and consequences. Best for structured environments, but overuse can stifle creativity and engagement.

6. Contingency Theory
‚Ü≥ No single leadership style works in every situation. Success depends on aligning leadership style with the circumstances.

7. Situational Leadership
‚Ü≥ Flexibility is key. Leaders adjust their approach based on their team‚Äôs skill and motivation, shifting between hands-on coaching and hands-off delegation.

8. Participative Leadership
‚Ü≥ Decisions aren‚Äôt made in isolation. This democratic style fosters collaboration and innovation‚Äîused by companies like Microsoft to drive success.

9. Adaptive Leadership ‚Äì Resilient-Change
‚Ü≥ Leaders navigate uncertainty, embrace challenges, and drive innovation in evolving environments.

What would you add to my list?

 Repost to inspire your network!

Have you ever struggled with getting information from a colleague you were taking over from?

The other day I was speaking to a friend of mine who had mentioned a situation at work and I was immediately taken back to when I was in a new BA role and the person assigned to transfer their knowledge to me was a supreme gatekeeper.

They would:
- give vague responses
- withhold or gloss over key information
- behave like they were the busiest person in the office and I need to jump hurdles to get access to them

I figured it was one of two things:

- they were protective of their knowledge, skeptical of change, or just overwhelmed or

- they liked the power that came from with being the "only one in the know."

Regardless, I had tasks to complete and my credibility to uphold so here is what I did:

Instead of asking open-ended questions like "Can you walk me through this process?", I'd ask targeted ones like:
‚ÄúWhat are the exact steps you follow when submitting X?‚Äù

When they'd share something, I would repeat it back and document it and say something along the lines of
‚ÄúJust to confirm, you do A, then B, then C, correct?‚Äù

If they‚Äôre being intentionally difficult, I'd loop in a neutral party, I'd pull in my manager: ‚ÄúI want to make sure we‚Äôre aligned on expectations for this transfer‚Äîcan we all meet for 15 minutes?‚Äù

I'd find ways to connect with them by being curious about them instead of always wanting something from them; I'd as about their experience or challenges like‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the biggest challenge with this system?‚Äù

Bottomline though, you can‚Äôt control how people act, but you can control how you navigate them.

As BAs, we don‚Äôt just gather requirements, we also know how to get information, even from the toughest sources.

Have you ever dealt with a difficult knowledge transfer?
How did you handle it? Let's chat in the comment section.

Stop Waiting. Start Saving.

One of the biggest mistakes I see solo entrepreneurs (and honestly, most people) make is waiting to start saving.

Waiting for income to stabilize.
Waiting to pay off debt.
Waiting to feel "ready."

But here‚Äôs the thing‚Äîwaiting can cost you years of lost growth.

The best time to start? Now. Even small steps add up.

Here‚Äôs how to make it easy:

 Automate your savings so it happens without thinking.
 Use tax-advantaged accounts when possible.
 If your income fluctuates, set a baseline savings amount. Then, when you have a great month, save a percentage of the extra.

Warren Buffett puts it best:

 ‚ÄúSomeone is sitting in the shade today because someone planted a tree a long time ago.‚Äù

The amount matters less than the habit. Start planting those seeds today.

5 proven tips to get better results from your cold calls. 

This is so TikTok-coded‚Ä¶ lets see how much LinkedIn hates (or loves) it.


 In 2025, you MUST take a LAYERED approach to each sales outreach channel.

This means you 1st, must take a multi-channel approach (I suggest phone, email + one more like social, events, direct mail etc).

THEN you must figure out how to go deep within each channel.


 Here is how it works for the phone:

*** watch the video for the 5 tips all the way through so LinkedIn shows this post to more people ***

DON'T only use the phone to smash through cold calls


 DO leave voicemails

DON'T wing those voicemails

DON'T spend the entire voicemail pitching your product

DO use the voicemail to reference another touch in your outreach


 DO explore texting

Be V careful about local rules about texting because it's usually opt-in if you are doing it cold, but if there a chance to send a text or even a VOICENOTE after a phone call to mix it up with voicemails??

 DO get creative

Can you go even harder and send a meme of GIF via text message?

Maybe even a video?



 Test a layered approach with your ICP. Not every channel or every layer within a channel will work for every ICP (obviously), but you only know if you try new strategies.

In 2025, outbound sales success depends on breaking out of the mold.


 What is your # 1 cold calling tip?

This is my top sales enablement  

When sales reps aren‚Äôt using the tools, messaging, or playbooks provided - enablement blames the reps.


 My pushback -

If your enablement resources were truly valuable, reps would jump at the chance to use them?

Spoiler: The answer is yes.

I don't know any sales reps who don't want an easier way to sell more.


 3 of the biggest misses I see. # 3 is the worst.

Ô∏è You‚Äôre delivering from the top down, not the front lines.

Resources created without rep input usually miss the mark on what actually works for the people doing the job every dang day.

Fix it:

Work with your top performers to build tools that reflect reality, not theory.


Ô∏è Your enablement isn‚Äôt connected to outcomes.

Reps aren‚Äôt interested in abstract ideas.

They need to know how the content you provide will help them close more deals now.

Fix it:

Talk the same way your reps do. Not about long-term gains, but about immediate gains that can be easily captured or pains that can be avoided.


Ô∏è You‚Äôre creating friction, not removing it.

*** This is the biggest challenge I see***

Enablement forgets that the biggest hurdle is change.

Change is so hard because it requires people to abandon familiar routines, take risks with uncertainty, and trust that the new way will actually deliver better results (often without immediate proof).

Change management is the hardest part of their job.

Fix it:

Stop trying to roll out big ambitious changes in a silo without earning the right to ask your sales team to trust and follow your lead.


TL:DR:

Enablement isn‚Äôt about creating more ‚Äústuff.‚Äù It‚Äôs about creating trust.

If your reps aren‚Äôt engaged, it's probably because change management is hard as heck.

Your tools, playbooks, scripts, trainings etc are probably awesome.

If you want better results in 2025, focus more on earning the right to ask your reps to trust you.


What is your biggest ?

postsData.content:
Does your mind ever get stuck in a loop worrying about something?

That was me last week. For some reason, my mind was buzzing with doubtful thoughts.

First, I was worrying about a new project. Then I spiraled into worries about my business, my future, and all the bad ‚Äúwhat ifs‚Äù‚Ä¶oh, it got dramatic in my head.

Deep down, I knew these were just untrue negative thoughts. But my mind kept talking back: ‚Äúbut, Emma, what if they ARE true?‚Äù

When I‚Äôm stuck in this kind of mental gridlock, I turn to a different kind of solution.

I ask for a sign that everything is going to be OK.

Specifically, I asked for that sign to be a hummingbird.

(You can still see the odd hummingbird in winter in Oregon, so my worrying mind hoped I would see one.)

That afternoon, I went to a new Trader Joe‚Äôs (a fun little US supermarket) with my daughters. We were at the checkout and my daughter shouted: ‚ÄúMama, LOOK! Hummingbirds!‚Äù

She pointed behind us at a massive wall mural of three hummingbirds ‚Äî and I laughed because the sign was so big and clear. And it reflected what I already knew in my heart: that everything was going to be OK.

So if you find yourself looping on something worrisome and scary, and you want to know that it‚Äôs going to be OK, ask for a specific sign.

It can be anything: a purple flower, a unicorn, even Elvis.

And then give it a few days. Your sign might not come in the form you expect. Instead of seeing a rainbow, you might hear a song on the radio about a rainbow.

But when you get the sign, you‚Äôll know.

I regularly ask for signs, and the more you do it, the more you trust them.

Have you received a sign lately?

comments.commentText: Oh my! Yes, I got my sign last week: Copyhackers approved my article pitch.
Auroriele congrats! That is awesome

postsData.commentAdded: What a wonderful reminder, Emma! Asking for a sign is a powerful way to shift our mindset. Love the creativity in your approach! üåü‚ú®

postsData.content:
60% of new managers fail in their first 24 months.

Truth: They don't fail. We fail them

The 3 core reasons behind the 60% failure rate

1/ Lack of Management Training

Being a top performer doesn't teach how to lead.
Most new managers never learn:
‚Ü≥ How to delegate effectively
‚Ü≥ How to give clear, constructive feedback
‚Ü≥ How to set goals and prioritize effectively

2/ Confuse Management with Leadership

Management and leadership are not the same.

Most new managers focus only on:
‚Ü≥ Organizing teams and tracking metrics
‚Ü≥ Planning projects and managing tasks
‚Ü≥ Overlooking vision, motivation, and trust‚Äîkey leadership elements

3/ Ineffective Change Management

Change is constant and most struggle to navigate it.

Most new managers:
‚Ü≥ Resist change instead of leading through it
‚Ü≥ Focus on stability rather than adaptability
‚Ü≥ Fail to gain clarity, and guide with confidence

They don't fail. We fail them

The majority of new manager failure is avoidable.

Attached: 

10 Critical Mindset Shifts
to help new managers become great leaders.

postsData.content:
The #1 Leadership Skill You Can‚Äôt Afford to Ignore

Imagine walking into a meeting where everyone speaks their mind freely, knowing their ideas will be heard‚Äînot judged. No second-guessing. No politics. Just real, open dialogue. That‚Äôs the power of trust. Without trust, teams fall apart. With it? They do their best work.

‚ÄúTrust is the glue of life. It's the most essential ingredient in effective communication.‚Äù ‚Äì Stephen Covey

Let‚Äôs be real‚Äîwithout trust, no amount of strategy will save your team. So how do you actually build it?

 Lead with transparency ‚Äì Be open about challenges and decisions. People trust what they understand.
 Follow through on commitments ‚Äì Reliability fosters credibility.
 Encourage psychological safety ‚Äì When people feel safe to share ideas, innovation flourishes.

In my work with leaders, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how trust transforms teams from merely functioning to truly excelling. It‚Äôs not just a ‚Äúnice-to-have‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation for productivity, engagement, and collaboration.

 What‚Äôs one thing you do to build trust in your team? Drop your thoughts below! ‚¨áÔ∏è

comments.commentText: Such a powerful point, trust truly is the foundation of high-performing teams, and building it through transparency and consistency creates an environment where collaboration and innovation thrive.
Absolutely, Jon. Transparency and consistency are key.

"Follow through on commitments", it is amazing how often leaders forget this one simple rule. I don't see it as generally being malicious or cruel, it is more that they tend to make a promise without realizing it, because it means more to the employee than it does to them.
How do you ensure reliability from leaders?
Great point Rebecca. I encourage leaders to put regular checkin-in on their calendar to keep commitments top of mind.

postsData.name:
Ani Filipova
Ani Filipova
postsData.content:
Hiring based on skills alone is a mistake.

Experience looks good on paper, but character defines success.

If you want to uncover  a candidate‚Äôs mindset, values, and motivation ask these 14 questions:

1. If money wasn‚Äôt an issue and you could do any job, what would it be?
‚Üí Reveals passion, natural drive, and what fuels their energy.

2. What was the last book, TV show, or film you really enjoyed?
‚Üí Shows how they think, what they value, and how they unwind.

3. When was the last time you felt proud at work, and why?
‚Üí Uncovers what success means to them‚Äîimpact, recognition, or financial gain.

4. What would you do if you knew you were going to miss a work deadline?
‚Üí Tests accountability, problem-solving, and honesty under pressure.

5. What do you think you owe an employer, and what do they owe you?
‚Üí Exposes their work ethic, expectations, and loyalty potential.

6. What‚Äôs your ideal work environment?
‚Üí Helps assess if they‚Äôll thrive in your company culture.

7. How do you like to receive praise?
‚Üí Identifies their feedback preferences‚Äîregular validation or quiet acknowledgment.

8. What are your top three strengths‚Äîand three weaknesses you‚Äôre actively working on?
‚Üí Reveals humility, self-improvement, and a growth mindset.

9. What‚Äôs something you strongly believe in that most people disagree with?
‚Üí Shows independent thinking, conviction, and confidence in their values.

10. If you had to teach someone something complex in 5 minutes, how would you do it?
‚Üí Assesses communication skills, clarity of thought, and patience.

11. If you could change one decision from your past, what would it be and why?
‚Üí Tests honesty, self-reflection, and whether they learn from their mistakes.

12. What do you do when you completely disagree with your manager?
‚Üí Reveals conflict resolution skills, emotional intelligence, and maturity.

13. How do you handle working with someone you don‚Äôt like?
‚Üí Assesses professionalism, collaboration, and ability to separate emotions from work.

14. If you had to make a difficult decision that would disappoint some people, how would you handle it?
‚Üí Tests ethical reasoning, leadership skills, and emotional intelligence.

 Hiring managers: Use these in your next interview.
 Candidates: Be ready for these.
 Save this for later - great hires start with great questions.

Repost to help others make better hiring decisions and follow mefor more content like this.

comments.commentText: These questions can help uncover a candidate's mindset, values, and motivation, leading to better hiring decisions.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on character and mindset can transform hiring practices. These questions are a must for uncovering true potential!

postsData.content:
Referral shock. 

Years ago I was in a group with someone who was offered a project they couldn‚Äôt take on.

They asked if anyone in the group was interested and qualified.

I raised my hand and got the introduction.

I spoke with the potential client and landed the gig.

When I let the referrer know, and thanked them, they wrote back and asked me to ‚Äúsend their fee.‚Äù

OK.

I was really surprised.

No fee had been mentioned up until then, and they were asking for 30% of the project fee.

My surprise turned to shock.

30% is a HUGE chunk on custom work.

I paid up, because it was the right thing to do.

I also lost all respect for that person and was very careful with any referrals after that. I was sure to ask what the expectations were.

Funnily enough, I never ran across anyone else with an expectation of payment.

But. I was prepared to dodge the bullet.

What‚Äôs your experience with referrals? Any good stories? Any scary ones?

comments.commentText: Whoa! How shady. They should have told you that upfront.

postsData.commentAdded: What a surprising experience! Its crucial to clarify expectations upfront. Ive had positive referral stories, but this serves as a great reminder!

postsData.content:
11 Signs You Might Be A Micromanager

(and how to stop yourself)

Brilliant carousel from(a must follow!)

A micromanager is someone who
Suffocates talent without seeing it.

Your control is costing more than you think.

1. You can't go on vacation.
üü• Decision-making stops in your absence
 Create a team that runs without you

2. You only hear "Yes".
üü• Constant agreement masks fear
 Reward those who challenge you

3. You are the bottleneck.
üü• Everything sits in your inbox
 Empower reversible decisions

4. You can't think of the last question you asked.
üü• All telling, zero listening
 Lead with, "What are we missing?"

5. You never see mistakes.
üü• No risks means no growth
 Make failure safe - lead by example

6. Your best talent leaves.
üü• Top talent craves freedom
 Offer trust instead of control

7. You are in back-to-back meetings.
üü• Meetings mask insecurity
 Step out of meetings that don't need you

8. Your meetings are quiet.
üü• Silence signals fear
 Ensure everyone's input

9. You discourage skip-level meetings.
üü• All communication flows through you
 Understand what motivates each person

10. You can't name your employee's kids.
üü• Distance breeds disconnect
 Learn what drives each person

11. You're nearing burnout.
üü• Control exhausts everyone
 Freedom creates energy

The hardest truth about micromanagement:

It feels like dedication.
It looks like attention to detail.
But it's actually fear in disguise.

Strong leaders build strong teams.
Scared leaders build dependent ones.

Which sign hit the hardest?

Ô∏è Share to help other leaders
 Followfor more

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùóØùó≤ùóÆùòÇùòÅùòÜ ùóºùó≥ ùó∫ùó∂ùóøùóøùóºùóøùó∂ùóªùó¥? ùóúùòÅ ùóØùòÇùó∂ùóπùó±ùòÄ ùòÅùóøùòÇùòÄùòÅ ùóÆùóªùó± ùóπùó∂ùó∏ùóÆùóØùó∂ùóπùó∂ùòÅùòÜ.

Being patience doesn‚Äôt mean being passive or indecisive. 

On the contrary.
It means acknowledging that not everything needs to be addressed right this moment.

Some of the best leaders know,
 when to wait
 when to let a conversation simmer,
 when to give someone the time to process, or
 when to step back and let the team take the lead.

Patience is what allows you to navigate these moments without losing sight of the bigger picture.

Are you curious about how to use patience as a leadership tool? Keep on reading!

Thank you, Anil Narain ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£ Matai ‡§Æ‡§ü‡§à. It‚Äôs amazing how embracing this mindset shifts everything.

Patience is often an overlooked yet transformative leadership quality. The ability to slow down, reflect, and allow processes to unfold naturally is a sign of true leadership maturity. Rushing decisions may lead to short-term results, but cultivating patience fosters trust, psychological safety, and long-term resilience within teams.

I believe that patience is not about passiveness, but rather about strategic intent. It enables leaders to listen more deeply, empower their teams, and make more thoughtful, sustainable decisions.

The most effective leaders know when to act swiftly and when to pause, giving space for ideas and people to develop.
